I have my own way to avoid tangling my earplugs

Here’s my advice:
•make the “i love you” sign with your hand 🤟 . make sure the two upright fingers are splayed out to the side a bit.
•place the headphones so the earpieces are against your palm and the cord travels up between the two middle folded down fingers
•wrap the cord around the two upright fingers in a figure 8 shape
•relax the upright fingers so there’s room to remove the cord
•take the headphones off you hand and shove it in a pocket
It basically never knots like this.

I have a solution. Hold the buds, and wrap the cord once around, dragging the plug over your hand. Hold that plug next to the buds before it slips through your hand. You should be holding a loop or bite. This large loop gets wrapped around your hand to create the coil. it’s about 4in (10cm) long. This length is actually determined by the size of your your coil. Wrap the loop or bite through the center of the coil and around the coil of wire 3 to 4 times in order to tuck the loop over the ear buds. The last bit of the loop or buy wraps around the coil holding everything tight,The tension will keep the loop on the buds and plug if you start the coil just before the earbuds and plug.
It is very important to remove the loop from the center the same 3-4 time in order to avoided knots.
I’ve used this method for years it works well and they have never gotten tangled.

I do knot have this problem.

Wrap the earbud-end of the headphone around your hand until you have half the length of your headphone cord left. Remove the wrapped portion from your hand, forming an O. Wrap the remainder of the headphone cord around the middle of the O, forming a figure 8. Reserve a small length of the cord and thread it through one of the holes in the figure 8. To unwrap without tangles, unthread the cord from the 8 and let it fall loose. No more tangles.

Physics Girl did a video on this a while ago, and she presented a solution - wrap your headphones in a figure of eight*, rather than a circular pattern.
It sounded like a lot of nonsense to me, but it actually works - not (knot😉) 100% of the time, but certainly more often than not (knot😒).
*Wrap the figure of eight around your fingers, and carefully slide off.
You can also store your earbuds in a figure 8, which doesn't knot for some reason.

Wrap the cord several times around your fingers, pinch the middle of the bundle together and wrap a few times across where you pinched, thread the loose end trough both loops and tighten. You should be left with no hard creased cord and something resembling a coiled climbing rope.

I coil all of my rope using the “zero net twist” method. I learned this in doing AV tech coiling XLP CABLES.

Because the rope is so orderly and has so little stress, it is much less likely to move out of place. Shove them in a pouch and bam no knots ever!

It can also be understood by thermodynamics, more specifically by entropy.

There's just a few, very specific arrangements (low entropy states) where these wires are not tangled up, but countless trillions in which are tangled. And as we know, entropy always increases, thus the nicely ordered bundle of wire will, if given energy from the outside (jostling, movement... what have you), find its way to a more disordered, higher entropy state and that is, by pure probability a knot.

I study audio engineering so I have to deal with all kind of cables all the time: theres a way to put them in a loop, first clockwise and then doing it counterclockwise, like an 8, but bending the second circle upwards so it looks like a zero, one way and then the other until you have a circle that goes inside of the loop and then outside. In the end you can tie them up with velcro and the cable never ever tangles, you can throw it and it unveils without any tangling and the copper doesnt get stiff and hard.
Fun fact. Knots can only exist in three dimentional space.

I managed to come to a pretty good solution to this when I learned how rope was made. You twist up two bundles of fibers in opposite directions, then when you hold them together they wind around each other. You can do this with cords. Fold the headphones in half once, then fold them over once more (so now you're dealing with 1/4 of the original length). Put your finger through the bottom loop and pull the cords taught, then twist them up gently. Fold the twisted cords over on themselves one last time and the two halves should wind together just like rope does. Simply secure it by putting the ear buds and/or audio jack through all of the adjacent loops. Tada! controlled tangles that are easy to transport and undo at will.
